Hip adjustment set:
This option allows you to change the configuration set (Default, A-H) for "Hip adjutsment", which can be defined under mocap options. Configuration is applied on a per-pose basis (full body mocap uses an independent configuration). Press â¬…ï¸â¡ï¸ key to change value.

Shoulder adjust:
This option determines the resting angle of shoulder and how the shoulder angle responds to arm mocap. "Full" has the lowest resting angle for VRM model. "Upper half" doesn't change the resting angle and shoulder angle changes only if arms are raised above the shoulder. "None" disables any shoulder angle adjustment.

Mirror current pose:
This option mirrors the current pose/motion. All parameters, including "arm-as-leg" control, are also mirrored. Use hotkey Ctrl+M as a shortcut to mirror pose at any time.

Push current pose to list top:
This option pushes the current pose/motion to the top of the pose list, mainly for the convenience to use the pose hotkeys (Alt/Ctrl+Num1-9) when they can only cover the first 18 poses. Alternatively, you can change the order of the poses via drag and drop.

_translation_._default_: If your avatar's arm/shoulder size proportion is off the average, use this option to apply an offset to the arm's horizontal position, which can be useful if you want some specific actions such as touching both hands. Press â•â– key to change value. Default is "0%".
Use this option if your want your avatar's arm position to be higher or lower than the one detected by mocap. Press â•â– key to change value. Default is "0%".

During upper body mocap, use this setting to apply a rotation offset to the upper body of your avatar while rotating the root in the opposite direction, as if only your lower body is rotated while the upper body stays still. This can be useful if you are at a certain angle sideway to the camera instead of facing the camera straightly. Default is "0Â°".

Hide avatar on tracking loss:
During full body mocap, this setting determines whether to hide the avatar or just freeze the pose when body tracking is lost. When VMC is on, pseudo hiding of avatar is achieved by applying a vertical position offset (-999) to the avatar on the other side. Choose "non-VMC" to disable this behavior. Default is "non-VMC".

This setting determines the duration of avatar's hands/fingers (or feet/toes in "arm-as-leg" mode) moving into the position when your hands enter the screen during upper body mocap. Press â•â– key to change value. Default is "100%" (250ms).

_translation_._default_: By default, when using upper body mocap, hip position and rotation will be adjusted according to your upper body motion. This option determines the general weighting of the hip adjustment applied. Default is "100%".
This option determines the weighting of head motion to be included as part of the upper body motion. Default is "100%".

This option determines how the pitch part of the head rotation is used for hip adjustment. It can be a negative value, meaning the behavior of hip motion based on "Scale Y" and part of "Scale Z" settings will be inverted for the head rotation part. Default is "100%".

_translation_._default_: This option determines the degree of chest rotation offset based on head rotation. By default, the offset's rotation direction is the opposite of head rotation. Negative value inverts the direction. Default is "20%".

_translation_._default_: When this option is "100%", hip moves downwards when you lean forward, upwards when you lean backward, and sideways when you turn sideways. When this option is "0%", hip moves downwards no matter you lean forward or backward, and there is no hip movement when you turn sideways. Default is "66%".

This option determines the scaling of movement along the X axis. By default, hip moves to the left when you leans to the right (or turns right when "Y-axis adjustment" is on), and hip moves to the right when you leans to the left. A negative value inverts this behavior. Default is "100%".

_translation_._default_: This option determines the scaling of movement along the Y axis. By default, hip moves downwards when you leans forward, and hip moves upwards when you leans backward (when "Y-axis adjustment" is on). A negative value inverts this behavior. Default is "100%".

_translation_._default_: This option determines the scaling of movement along the Z axis. By default, hip moves backwards when you leans forward, and hip moves forward when you leans backward. A negative value inverts this behavior. Default is "100%".

_translation_._default_: By default, hip rotates according to the rotation of your upper body. This option determines the degree of rotation. Negative value means the direction of rotation is inverted. Default is "100%".

_translation_._default_: When close to camera, hip adjustment settings are fully applied during full body mocap. This option determines how much the settings should be applied when no longer close to the camera (i.e. hips visible) during full body mocap. Default is "0%".

_translation_._default_: This option determines how much you want the hip motion to be smoothened. Default is "0%".

This option place colliders to various parts of avatar's body, which react with hands and arms to prevent them from overlapping the body parts. You can choose to enable "Full" mode to support both full body and upper body mocap, or just upper body mocap (including full body when close to camera). Default is "Upper body mocap".

This option determines the size of the collider. For example, if your avatar model has big breast, you may need to increase the size to over 100%. "0%" effectively turns off the collider. Press â¬…ï¸â¡ï¸ key to change value. Default is "125%" for chest, "0%" for head, and "100%" for other parts.

_translation_._default_: This option determines the type of reaction when collider and hand collide. "Z-push" pushes your hand backward in the Z direction, while "Sphere" lets your hand slide on a sphere-like surface. Default is "Z-push".

This option enhances the sense of depth of avatar's arms by utilizing the data of hand tracking. This value determines how much you want the hand tracking data to override arm tracking data from the body mocap. Depth adjustment applies to upper body mocap, or full body mocap when close to the camera. Default is "50%".

Depth adjustment is calculated based on the comparison of your palm's size and shoulder width. Smaller value fits smaller hands/wider shoulder, while large value fits bigger hands/narrower shoulder. Default is "22%".
This option determines how much you want to scale the value of depth up or down. Smaller scale draws your hands closer to your body, while larger scale extends your arm's reach. Default is "50%".

This option stabilizes the default arms tracking from body mocap and reduces false positive detections when hands are going on and off the screen, by utilizing the hands tracking data. This option applies in upper body mocap, or when this option is "ON" and you are close to camera. Default is "ON".

This option determines the amount of time required to stabilize arm tracking, which improves the result but increases lag for hands to show up on screen. You can just leave it to the default value in most cases. Default is "0" (no delay).

_translation_._default_: When enabled, the hand position from hand tracking will be used in favor of the one from body tracking. Percentage determines the duration to fade out hand tracking when it fails. You may want to lower the percentage if arm motion is vigorous or hand tracking condition is poor. Default is "20%".
press â•â– key to change value

When enabled, this option constrains the tracking region of hands by using data from body tracking, which is generally more effective than tracking the whole screen when you are far away from the camera. Default is "Auto" (i.e. enabled for full body mocap, disabled for upper body mocap).

When enabled, the processing of hand tracking will be separated from body tracking and run on a web worker. "Parallel" runs parallelly without sync, aiming to give priority for body mocap to achieve higher fps, but possibly lower fps for hand tracking. "Synced" provides less fps boost but syncs mocap result as if web worker is off. Default is "OFF".

_translation_._default_:
Eye tracking:
Sometimes you may want to turn eye tracking off if eyes are covered (e.g. sunglasses) or the tracking condition is poor. Otherwise, some bad tracking results can happen. Auto blink will be on when eye tracking is off. Default is "ON".

Blink LR sync:
For various reasons, blink tracking may not be ideal and lead to some size differences between the eyes that don't look good. Turn on this option to synchronize the blink of both eyes, but lose the ability to wink. Default is "OFF".

_translation_._default_:
Blink clarity:
This option determines the contrast between eye open and close status. Use a higher value if you have a hard time fully opening or closing your avatar's eyes, or activating a full blink. Default is "Normal".

Auto blink:
Sometimes blink tracking is hardly noticeable due to poor lighting and various conditions. Turn on this option to allow your avatar to blink automatically. Default is "OFF".

Auto "look at camera":
Sometimes you may want your avatar to look at the camera, as if you are always looking at your audience, regardless of where you are actually looking at. This option can be toggled via hotkey (<hotkey>). Default is "OFF".

_translation_._default_:
Eye bone rotation (press â•â– key to change value):
For avatar models that use eye bone rotation, sometimes the rotation degree can be either too small or too large. Adjust this setting to fit your taste. In the case of ARKit/PerfectSync model, sometimes you may need to set it to 0% if eye bone rotation is actually redundant. Default is "100%".

_translation_._default_:
Mouth tracking sensitivity:
This option determines the sensitivity of mouth tracking when mouth motion is subtle. "Very high/Max" boosts mid-range mouth blendshape values as well. Lower the setting if avatar's mouth is open even when idle. Default is "High".

AI model inference device:
This option determines whether to use CPU or GPU to run the face tracking model. While GPU inference is slightly faster, face tracking model is fairly optimized for CPU, and by using CPU instead, you save some valuable GPU resources usable for other tasks. Default is "CPU".

_translation_._default_:
Body leaning tracking:
This option compares your head size with the size data collected during the calibration process to determine how much the body of the avatar should lean forward. This option applies when you are close to the camera. Default is "Normal".

_translation_._default_:
Emotion tracking options:
By default, face tracking reads your facial expressions and attempts to match some standard expressions from your avatar model, such as joy/fun, sorrow, angry, and optionally surprise and blush. Adjust the general weighting or weighting of each individual expression to suit your taste.
Press â¬…ï¸â¡ï¸ key to change value
press â¬…ï¸â¡ï¸ key to change value
This option determines the general weighting of all expressions detected via emotion tracking. Default is "75%".
Activate the joy/fun expression simply by making a smiling face. This is natural, straight forward and you probably want to keep this expression detection on all the time. Default is "100%".
Activate the angry expression by making a side pout on either left or right side. Lower the percentage if it is often misactivated. Default is "100%".
Activate the sorrow expression by frowning, or pulling your lower lip upward and making a standard sad face. Lower the percentage if it is often misactivated. Default is "100%".

Activate the surprised expression by raising your eyebrows and lowering your jaw. Note that not all 3D models have this expression. Lower the percentage if it is often misactivated. Default is "100%".

XR Animator supports the tracking of ARKit 52 blendshapes, with the exception of a few, including "tongueOut". Turn on this option to allow XR Animator to estimate the tongue out motion by analyzing the other mouth blendshape data. Lower the percentage if it is often misactivated. Default is "100%".

_translation_._default_: Depending on each individual avatar model's settings, some models may have other detectable expressions. Lower the percentage if they are often misactivated. Default is "100%".

When non-zero, this option enables the use of AI to detect emotions, which is more accurate than the default emotion tracking, at the expense of extra system resource usage. Percentage value determines sensitivity. Percentage value for each individual emotion applies to this feature as well. Default is "0%".

_translation_._default_:
Interval:
This setting determines the detection interval. Shorter interval increases the number of detections per second, at the expense of extra system resource usage. Default is "500ms".

This setting determines how dominant "Neutral" should be over other emotions, and how much opposite emotions (e.g. happy vs sad) should cancel out each other. Lower value allows various emotions to coexist at the same time. Default is "50%".
This setting determines the weighting of vowel blendshapes (a,i,u,e,o). Lower this setting if some emotion blendshapes distort the vowel blendshapes. Default is "100%".

Calibration options:
Whenever face tracking starts, mocap data from the first few seconds will be analyzed and calibrated to better fit the user's face. These options allow you to reset the calibration, export the current calibration to an external JSON file, or import a previously exported calibration.

Drop a JSON file containing face calibration data.

_translation_._default_:
Detection score threshold<press_to_change_value>:
This setting determines the score threshold for an object to be considered successfully detected from a hidden state. Hidden state is either when an object hasn't appeared for the first time, or after it has been detached from hand. Higher score threshold prevents random false-positive detection. Default is "50%".

Tracking score threshold<press_to_change_value>:
This setting determines the score threshold for an object to be considered successfully tracked continuously. Lower score threshold makes it easier for an object to be continuously tracked. Default is "20%".

Detection interval:
This setting determines the detection interval. Shorter interval increases the number of detections per second, at the expense of extra system resource usage. Default is "500ms".

Mocap data smoothing:
This option determines how much smoothing should be applied to real-time mocap and motion recording. Less smoothing preserves more motion details, but increases jitters during subtle motion. "Min" uses no extra smoothing other than the minimum required. Default is "Normal".

_translation_._default_: If your webcam is angled up or down, offset it to cancel avatar's tilting.

Tilt adjustment:
If your webcam is angled up or down, enable this option to apply an angle offset to cancel avatar's tilting. Angle offset is fully applied to head. A smaller weighting can be applied to body ("50%" by default), as body mocap is usually less sensitive to webcam tilting. Negative weighting means an opposite angle offset for body. Default is "OFF".

Clear bounding box:
XR Animator mocap can only track one person at the same time. When there are more than one person in the mocap source, sometimes the mocap AI can be tracking the wrong person. In such case, clear the bounding box of the current target to enforce the AI to track another person in the video.

_translation_._default_:
Status:
Click to turn this receiver on or off. "âš«" indicates this receiver is off. "ğŸ”´" indicates this receiver is on and waiting for external connection. "ğŸŸ¢" indicates this receiver is on and currently connected. Default is "OFF".

Face:
Turn on this setting if you are using independent face tracking. You can enable expression only, or with head rotation as well. "Absolute" means the head rotation is based on an independent orientation (e.g. screen for camera-based tracking) instead of relative to the avatar model. Default is "OFF".

Pose:
Turn on this setting if you are using any body tracking, such as VR trackers. Choose between "Upper body" or "Full body". This can be an all-in-one tracking, meaning face and hand tracking can be included as well. Default is "OFF".

_translation_._default_:
Image input handler:
By default, image input is treated as mocap source when this speech bubble is off. Setting it to "Wallpaper" allows you to change wallpaper by dropping an image anywhere and anytime.

3D wallpaper:
When enabled, a 3D wallpaper of the dropped image will be generated by using a depth map estimated by AI. Dynamic 3D camera effect that responds to avatar's motion such as "Camera face-locking" is needed for it to look 3D. Default is "ON".

Use this setting to shift the depth values to either end of the spectrum. Positive value shifts depth towards the camera, making closer objects look even closer. Negative value does the opposite. Default is "0%".

_translation_._default_:
Depth contrast<press_to_change_value>:
Use this setting to change the contrast of the depth values. Use a smaller contrast when some depth values are unnaturally stuck at either end of the spectrum, making them movable using the "Depth shift" setting. Default is "0%".

Depth blur<press_to_change_value>:
Use this setting to blur the depth. Larger value smooths changes betwen adjacent depth values. Default is "2px".

Depth smoothing<press_to_change_value>:
XR Animator supports using converted video file as 3D animated wallpaper. However, depth map of a video can be inconsistent across frames, causing distortion. Increase this setting to reduce distortion. "100%" practically freezes the depth map on the first/current frame. Default is "80%".

_translation_._default_: press â¬…ï¸â¡ï¸ key to change value

Camera face-locking<press_to_change_value>:
This setting determines how much the camera should respond to the motion of the avatar's head. Default is "100%".

Camera face-locking<press_to_change_value>:
This setting determines the movement of the camera's look-at target. Positive value means the target moves in the same direction as the head. The difference between this setting and "Movement X/Y" determines how much the camera moves and rotates. Camera tends to rotate more when the difference is large. Default is "-20%".

Movement X/Y<press_to_change_value>:
This setting determines the movement of the camera. Positive value means the camera moves in the same direction as the head. Negative values moves in the opposite direction, which effectively amplifies the visual movement of the avatar. Default is "-60%".

_translation_._default_:
Movement X/Y<press_to_change_value>:
This setting determines the movement of the camera in Z direction. Positive value means the camera moves in the same direction as the head. A large positive value stabilizes the visual size of the avatar due to Z movement during full body mocap/prerecorded motion. Default is "0%".

_translation_._default_:
Min distance<press_to_change_value>:
When "Movement Z" is non-zero, this setting determines the minimum distance between avatar and camera (in meter) before the camera starts moving. This effectively prevents the camera from getting to close to the avatar, no matter how the avatar moves. Default is "1".

Vertical constraint<press_to_change_value>:
This setting determines how much the camera position should be adjusted so that the vertical position of avatar's head is within the screen. At 100%, the vertical position of avatar's head will basically be fixed at the screen center. Default is "0%".

Smooth time<press_to_change_value>:
This setting determines the smoothing time of the camera motion. Larger value smooths the camera motion, especially when avatar's movement is vigorous, while smaller value makes the camera motion more responsive. Default is "0.5".

Camera auto-zoom:
When enabled, the 3D camera will automatically adjust the zoom distance to fill the screen with the display of avatar model by a certain percentage, no matter how you rotate the camera. This applies to all poses and motions other than the default pose for upper and full body mocap. Press â¬…ï¸â¡ï¸ key to change value. Default is "OFF".

Audio visualizer:
XR Animator supports various audio visualization effects when a music file is dropped to the app. Turn off this option if you don't want the default "circular spectrum" audio visualizer to show up when music plays. Default is "ON".
